title: AB 2886
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 2707.2 of the Unemployment Insurance Code is amended to include provisions for the department to consider employer-submitted facts for claimant eligibility, notify claimants of determinations, and allow for appeals to an administrative law judge within 20 days. "Good cause" for appeal extensions is defined as mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect. This section is effective until March 1, 2018, and will be repealed after that date. Section 2707.2 of the Unemployment Insurance Code requires the department to review employer-submitted facts for claimant eligibility, notify claimants of determinations, and allow appeals to an administrative law judge within 30 days. "Good cause" for appeal extensions includes mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect. This section becomes effective on March 1, 2018. Section 2707.4 allows claimants to protest the accuracy of computation or recomputation within 20 days, with the option to extend for good cause. The department will consider protests and notify claimants of the decision. Appeals can be made in the manner prescribed in Section 2707.2. "Good cause" includes mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect. This section is effective until March 1, 2018. Section 2707.4 of the Unemployment Insurance Code allows claimants to protest computation or recomputation accuracy within 30 days, extendable for good cause. The department will review protests and notify claimants of the decision. Appeals can be made as per Section 2707.2. "Good cause" includes mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect. Effective from March 1, 2018. Section 2707.7 allows individuals to appeal within 30 days of notice, extending the 20-day period. This section is effective until March 1, 2018. Section 2707.8 is also added to the Unemployment Insurance Code. Section 2707.8 of the Unemployment Insurance Code outlines the process for administrative law judges to review appeals, with a 30-day limit for further appeal to the appeals board. "Good cause" for extension includes mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect. Section 2737 of the Unemployment Insurance Code allows for an appeal to an administrative law judge within 20 days of receiving a notice of overpayment determination. The judge will review the findings and make a final decision, which can be further appealed to the appeals board within 20 days. The 20-day period for appeal can be extended for good cause. Section 2737 of the Unemployment Insurance Code allows for an appeal to an administrative law judge within 20 days of receiving a notice of overpayment determination. Good cause for appeal includes mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect. This section is in effect until March 1, 2018, and will be repealed after that date. Section 2737 of the Unemployment Insurance Code allows for an appeal to an administrative law judge within 30 days of receiving a notice of overpayment determination. The administrative law judge will review the appeal and make a final decision, which can be further appealed to the appeals board within 30 days. The 30-day period for appeal may be extended for good cause. Section 2737.5 of the Unemployment Insurance Code allows individuals to appeal overpayment determinations to an administrative law judge within 30 days, with good cause including mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect. This section will be in effect until March 1, 2018.
